Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: The Great American Biotic Interchange (GABI)--The Panama Connection
Award.AbstractNarration:
This three-year project focuses on professional research experiences for middle and high school STEM teachers through investigations of the Great American Biotic Interchange (GABI). Each year 10 teachers (in diverse fields including biology, chemistry, earth and environmental sciences, and oceanography) and three to five professional paleontologists will participate in a four-phase process of professional development, including: a (1) pre-trip orientation (May); (2) 12 days in Panama in July collecting fossils from previously reported, as well as newly discovered, sites; (3) a post-trip on-line (cyber-enabled) Community of Practice; and (4) a final wrap-up at the end of each cohort (December). In addition, some of the teachers may also elect to partner with scientists in their research laboratories, principally located in California, Florida, and New Mexico. The partners in Panama are from the Universidad Autónoma de Chiriquí (UNACHI), including faculty and students, as well as STEM teachers from schools in Panama. Teachers that participate in this RET will develop lesson plans related to fossils, paleontology, evolution, geology, past climate change, and related content aligned with current STEM standards.

The GABI, catalyzed by the formation of the Isthmus of Panama during the Neogene, had a profound effect on the evolution and geography of terrestrial organisms throughout the Americas and marine organisms globally. For example, more than 100 genera of terrestrial mammals dispersed between the Americas, and numerous marine organisms had their interoceanic distributions cut in half by the formation of the Isthmus. Rather than being considered a single event that occurred about 4 million years ago, the GABI likely represents a series of dispersals over the past 10 million years, some of which occurred before full closure of the Isthmus. New fossil discoveries in Panama resulting from the GABI RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) are thus contributing to the understanding of the complexity and timing of the GABI during the Neogene.

This award is being co-funded with the Office International and Integrative Activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The research goal of this project was to advance understanding of the Great American Biotic Interchange (GABI) using fossil evidence from North America during the Neogene. Field work was conducted during each of four field seasons (2014, 2015, 2016, 2017) in Florida, Panama, and New Mexico. Approximately 1,000 fossil vertebrate and invertebrate specimens were curated into research collections at the University of Florida and New Mexico Museum of Natural History. The former are being digitized and being placed in large aggregators including iDigBio and GBIF. The research produced during the project has been presented in about 20 talks and posters at national professional meetings and published in eight peer-reviewed papers so far; more are anticipated. In addition, the GABI RET is highlighted in several places in the PI/PDs book entitled Broader Impacts of Science on Society (2019, Cambridge University Press).

 

Broader Impacts

This RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) project supported a core group and learning network of 40 teachers and a dozen scientists, the latter including senior and early career professionals, working together in the field to collect fossils and advance knowledge of the GABI. The teachers gained valuable skills, experience, and scientific knowledge that they were then able to translate into the classroom via the development of about 25 lesson plans, all of which are aligned to relevant standards (e.g., NGSS). Project staff and students conducted visits to about 15 classrooms during the course of this project. A formal summative evaluation conducted by an external evaluator documented the efficacy of this project related to the IM and BI goals, activities, and outcomes. Previous studies have documented the benefit accrued to the teacher participants. However, the results of our summative project evaluation demonstrate that a previously unrealized benefit is accrued back to the scientists, i.e., find their participation to be a positive and rewarding professional development experience.

 

Project Summary

This project was funded by NSF's RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) program. This innovative program brings scientists and teachers together for professional development and to work for mutual benefit to advance research and education.

     The overarching research goal of this project was to advance understanding of the Great American Biotic Interchange (GABI) using fossil evidence from North America over the past 20 million years. The GABI refers to a time in earth history when the Isthmus of Panama formed via volcanic activity about 4 to 5 million years ago, resulting in a dry land connection (bridge) in what had previously been a seaway separating North and South America. This bridge had significant impact on the Earth's biodiversity: (1) it allowed terrestrial animals in North and South America to cross the land bridge; and (2) it closed a seaway south of Panama that previously allowed marine animals to migrate between the Pacific Ocean and Caribbean Sea.

     Field work was conducted during each of four field seasons (2014, 2015, 2016, 2017) in Florida, Panama, and New Mexico; i.e., in the northern part of the GABI. Based on the age of the fossils collected, we mostly studied the pre-GABI animals (invertebrates and vertebrates) that lived before the formation of the land bridge. Approximately 1,000 fossil vertebrate and invertebrate specimens were curated into research collections at the University of Florida and New Mexico Museum of Natural History. The fossils in the University of Florida collections are also being digitized, i.e., their electronic catalog data entries will be placed (aggregated) in large global scientific databases, including iDigBio and GBIF. The research produced during the project has been presented in about 20 talks and posters at national professional meetings and published in eight peer-reviewed papers so far; more are anticipated. Major discoveries include the description of new extinct mammal species and documenting new occurrences of species. For example, extinct elephant-like gomphotheres had not been known to exist in southern-most North America until the Ice Ages (Pleistocene), but we documented their presence 10 million years ago from near Lake Bayano in Panama.

     This GABI RET project supported a core group and learning network of about 40 teachers and a dozen scientists, the latter including senior and early career professionals (i.e., university students and postdoctoral researchers), working together in the field to collect fossils and advance knowledge of the GABI. The teachers gained valuable skills, experience, and scientific knowledge that they were then able to translate into the classroom via the development of about 25 lesson plans, all of which are aligned to relevant standards (e.g., NGSS). Project staff and students conducted visits to about 15 classrooms during this project. A formal evaluation conducted by an external evaluator documented the successes of this project related to its goals, activities, and outcomes. Our evaluation demonstrated that both the scientists and teachers greatly benefitted from this professional development and found their experiences rewarding.
